turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'm with a girl, Ralph.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Get ridda her. This is money inna bank.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I can't do that, Ralph, because somebody already brushed her off once tonight.

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: This is a good deal here, Marty.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hello, Ralph. How'd you make out with those nurses last night, Ralph?

turns.speaker: RALPH
turns.text: Oh man, you shoulda come with us last night, Marty. That one for you was a real lunatic. How'd you make out?

turns.speaker: MRS. FUSARI
turns.text: Your kid brother got married last Sunday, eh, Marty?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: That's right, Missus Fusari. It was a very nice affair.

turns.speaker: MRS. FUSARI
turns.text: That's the big tall one, the fellow with the moustache.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: No, that's my other brother, Freddie. My other brother Freddie, he's been married four years already. He lives down on Webb Avenue. The one who got married Sunday, that was my little brother, Nickie.

turns.speaker: MRS. FUSARI
turns.text: I thought he was a big tall fat fellow. Didn't I meet him here one time? Big tall, fat fellow, he tried to sell me life insurance?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: No, that's my sister Margaret's husband, Frank. My sister Margaret, she's married to the insurance salesman, and my sister Rose, she married a contractor. They moved to Detroit last year. And my other sister Frances, she got married about two and a half years ago in Saint John's Church on Kingsbridge Avenue. Oh, that was a big affair. Well, let's see now, that'll be about a dollar- seventy-nine. How's that with you?

turns.speaker: MRS. FUSARI
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: MRS. FUSARI
turns.text: When you gonna get married, Marty? You should be ashamed of yourself. All your brothers and sisters, they all younger than you, they married and they got children. I just saw your mother inna fruit shop, and she says to me, "Hey, you know a nice girl for my boy Marty?" Watsa matter with you? That's no way. Now you get married.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Missus Fusari, Missus Canduso over there, she's inna big hurry, and...

turns.speaker: MRS. FUSARI
turns.text: My son Frank, he was married when he was nineteen years old. Watsa matter with you?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: That's swell, Missus Fusari.

turns.speaker: MRS. FUSARI
turns.text: You should be ashamed of yourself.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: All right, Ginnie, don't get so excited.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: She's right. She's right. Young husband and wife, they should have their own home. And my sister Catherine, she's my sister, but I gotta admit, she's an old goat. And plenty-a times in my life, I feel like throwing the milk bottle at her myself. And I tell you now, as far as I'm concerned, if Catherine wantsa come live here with me and Marty, it's all right with me.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: That's very nice-a you, Aunt Theresa.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: We gotta ask Marty, of course.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: You just sit here, I gotta turn the fire on under the cooking.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Oh, he'll get married, don't worry, Aunt Theresa.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Well, I don't know. He sits arounna house alla time. You know a place he can go where he can find a bride?

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Well, there's the Stardust Ballroom. That's a kind of a big dance hall. Every Saturday night, it's just loaded with girls. It's a nice place to go. You pay seventy-seven cents. It used to be seventy-seven cents. It must be about a buck and half now. And you go in and you ask some girl to dance. That's how I met Virginia. Nice, respectable place to meet girls. You tell Marty, Aunt Theresa, you tell him, "Go to the Stardust Ballroom. It's loaded with tomatoes."

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: The Stardust Ballroom. It's loaded with tomatoes.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: He says okay, it's all right Catherine comes here.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Oh, Marty, thanks a lot. That really takes a load offa my mind.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: I just wanna thank you people again, because the situation was just becoming impossible.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Siddown, Thomas, siddown.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Hello, Aunt Theresa.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Hello, Thomas.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: I just this minute got the baby to sleep.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Aunt Theresa, we figure the best way to ask her is you say that you're very lonely, see? And wouldn't she come and keep you company, because that way, you see...

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Don't worry. I'm gonna take care-a the whole thing.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Ma, you want something to eat, some tuna fish?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Hey, why don't you go to the movie? Your mother and me, we're gonna be baby-sitter.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Hello, Aunt Theresa.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Hello, Thomas, how do you feel?

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Ah, my mother, she drives me crazy. I hadda beg her to let me drive her over here. The martyr. She always gotta be the big martyr.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: He coming home right now.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: So what happened, Aunt Theresa, about the milk bottle was my mother-in- law, she comes inna kitchen, Aunt Theresa, and she begins poking her head over my shoulder here and poking her head over my shoulder there, so then she begins telling me how I waste money and how I can't cook, and how I'm raising my baby all wrong, so she got me so nervous, I spilled some milk I was making for the baby...

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: She was here, you know, Wednesday, and I said, "Catherine, my sister..."

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: So she say, "You're spilling the milk." So she kept talking about these coupla drops of milk I spilled, so she got me so mad, so I said, "Mama, you wanna see me really spill some milk?" So I took the bottle, and I threw it against the door. I didn't throw it at her. That's just something she made up. She goes around telling everybody I threw the bottla milk at her. I didn't throw it anywheres near her. Well, I was sorry right away, you know, but she ran outta the house.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Well, I don't know what you want me to do, Virginia. If you want me, I'll go talk to her tonight.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Aunt Theresa, you got this big house here. I mean, you got this big house just for you and Marty. And I thought maybe Tommy's mother could come here and live with you and Marty.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Because I called up Tommy's brother Joe, and I said, "Joe, she's driving me crazy. Why don't you take her for a couple of years?" And he said, "Oh no!" I know I sound like a terrible woman...

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: No, Virginia, I know how you feel.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: I just can't stand it any more! Every minute of the day! Do this! Do that! I don't have ten minutes privacy with my husband! We can't even have a fight! We don't have no privacy! Everybody's miserable in our house!

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: I'm sorry we gotta rush like this...

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: That's all right, that's all right...

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: On accounta...

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I'm gonna see you tonight...

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: We didn't tell her anything yet. We thought that we'd leave it to you. We thought you'd put it like how you were lonely, and why don't she come to live with you. Because that way it looks like she's doing you a favor, insteada we're throwing her out, and it won't be so cruel on her. Do you want Tommy and me to stay here with you?

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: I think it be a better idea if you and Thomas go out, because otherwise she's gonna start a fight with you, and everybody's gonna be yelling.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Listen, let's go downa Kaplans' apartment. They told us to come down.

turns.speaker: MRS. PILLETTI
turns.text: Sure, sure.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Well, I'll tell you, Aunt Theresa...

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Lemme tell it, Tommy.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: We want you to do a very big favor for us, Aunt Theresa.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: That's very nice-a you, Aunt Theresa.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: How's Marty been lately, Aunt Theresa?

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Marty, I don't know how to tell you how much I appreciate what you and your mother are doing, because the kinda thing was happening in our house was Virginia was in the kitchen making some milk for the baby. So my mother comes in...

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Tommy, I promised the babysitter six o'clock.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Tommy!

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: I'll see you at mass tomorrow. We'll sit down and we'll discuss the whole thing.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Don't you think I feel lousy about this too?

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: All right, Ginnie. I don't wanna talk anymore about it.  I don't think I got one hour's sleep the whole night.  Last night was the first time in my life I ever heard my mother cry, you know that?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Tommy...

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: I don't wanna talk about it!

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: I know what you're gonna say. A man's gotta stop being his mother's baby sooner or later. How many times you gonna say it? She's my mother, you know. I oughta have some feelings about her, don't you think?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Why do you always put me inna position of being the louse?

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Virginia, I don't wanna hear no more about it!

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Tommy...

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: I don't wanna hear anymore about it, you hear me?

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Wadda you so sore about?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Oh shaddup, will you do me a favor?

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: What about the time she wanted to make an old-fashioned Italian dinner for my brother, but you wouldn't let her!?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Waddaya talking about?!!

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: Once a month you couldn't let her use the kitchen!

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: I told her she could use the kitchen any time she wanted...

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: ...You hadda be the boss inna kitchen alla time!

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: She don't wanna use my pots and pans!

turns.speaker: DAGO RED
turns.text: There's sort of a built-in prayer for the sick man to get well, but of course that's not the basic intention.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I don't care about the intention. I just know your Cross Action is a plus on our side. I've seen it come through four times.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: We wanted to tell you how you were helping us with your fixes.

turns.speaker: DAGO RED
turns.text: Well, sure, but I'm also worried about Walt Waldowski  Painless. His poker players got in an argument and asked him for a ruling, and he said what difference did it make, it was just a card game.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: How they goin', Losing Preacher? What do you hear from the Pope?

turns.speaker: DAGO RED
turns.text: You talked to Walt?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: He's parted his moorings.

turns.speaker: DAGO RED
turns.text: What do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Put in one of your fixes. Walt knows he's loused himself with the Church, but it's part of our plan to make him think he has the keys to the kingdom. Which he will think if you grease the skids for him.

turns.speaker: DAGO RED
turns.text: I don't think I can give absolution to a man who's about to commit suicide. It's a mortal sin.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: What is, Red, the intention or the act?

turns.speaker: DAGO RED
turns.text: I believe it takes both. I'd have to look it up.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Just use common sense. Your job is preventing sin, and the way to do that is give him your best Cross Action.

turns.speaker: DAGO RED
turns.text: Nice looking kid. Going to be okay?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: He'll live if that's what you mean. But somebody better be around when he comes to and finds out there's nothing left between his legs.

turns.speaker: DAGO RED
turns.text: What do I do with it Hawk? This is a little out of my line.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Didn't recognize you, Red. When you get the clamp all the way down, open it as wide as you can and see if you can close it on the artery.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Y'all were short a couple cutters and we're what the Army sent.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Don't you know the first thing you're supposed to do at a new post is present yourself to the commanding officer with your orders?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Reckon so, but we been boozing all day and you work up an appetite.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: You're welcome to one of these, whatever they are.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: They give you copies to burn.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Good. You've both been working close to the front.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Never this close.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: They've hit us on Cherry Hill. I just got word. We have our slack periods but when the action starts, you'll have more work in twelve hours than a civilian surgeon does in a week.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: I may need you to go to work practically immediately. But meanwhile perhaps you'd like to meet some of your fellow officers.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Just one for a start.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Yeah, maybe move that nurse in. She don't seem the type to keep you awake praying.

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: I have been in this Army a long time. I know just what you guys are up to. But there are limits...

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Yes, O'Reilly?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: How you, Radar?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: You boys'll have to go to work early.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: You fixing to add overtime to a twelve- hour day? The union ain't gonna like it.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What are you going to do with him?

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Well...  I was going to name you Chief Surgeon...  To consult on both shifts, yours and Frank's.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Hey, that's great, Henry! Good thinking!

turns.speaker: HENRY
turns.text: Stop him! Stop that man!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Sure, you just blindfold him first and tie him to a stake.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Now I got you for a witness, I'm going to try again. So far all I dragged out of him is he's from Bahston and he's only been in the Army two months.  Where were you when they drafted you?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Home.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: I mean, what were you doing? Were you a resident or on a staff someplace?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Hospital.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Which hospital?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Back home.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Is there any reason why we shouldn't know the name of it?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: No.  Or why you should.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Don't you use olives?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Where you think you are, boy? They probably never seen a olive in this country.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: How you, Walt? We was just fixing to have a nightcap.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Pour one for Painless.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Miss you, Walt.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: He said it for us all, Walt.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Pulse, slow, very little pressure.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Look at that right eye.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Epidural hematoma?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: I don't know what else. You've been that route a little, haven't you?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Not enough to be a pro.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: She had this shiny black hair piled up on her head, but later on she let it hang loose and I'll be damned if it didn't come all the way down to her ass.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: I've always had a hankering for blonde pussy myself. My wife's hair is a wonderful golden yellow, and this time of year it gets even lighter.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Okay, I'm a witness, but how do you prove who's right?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: There's only one way.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: It certainly isn't Henry's fault Hot Lips Houlihan doesn't like her name.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Or her figger.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Well, he's taken care of. Scratch one hot dog.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: You really think we hurt him that bad?

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Hell, no, all you did was knock the wind out of him. But he won't be playing any more football today.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Y'all mind the store.

turns.speaker: TRAPPER
turns.text: Four goddam months. And they don't even give you time off for good behavior.

turns.speaker: HO-JON
turns.text: Because is not democrash? All peoples created equal?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Hey, you been sneaking some reading outside the frigging Bible!

turns.speaker: HO-JON
turns.text: I have great interest for America, his peoples and his custom.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Good, because we got a fine old American custom we want to teach you. You know what these are?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: I don't think I should have opened my big mouth. Sorry, Ho-Jon.

turns.speaker: HO-JON
turns.text: That's okay. Live a little, learn a little.

turns.speaker: HO-JON
turns.text: You  must  open  me  up  again?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: No, Ho-Jon, we're not going to open you up.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Thou. For Thou art with me.  Welcome, welcome, welcome!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What the hell's going on here?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: This is Ho-Jon, my houseboy. Our houseboy. I'm teaching him English.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Where's he gonna use that kind of talk? 'The valley of the shadow of death.' Wait a minute, Ho-Jon...  I got something for you.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: But first will you please kindly shut the goddam door?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't drink intoxicants.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't believe it's right for you to involve a boy who's not seventeen years old yet...

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: The door, Frank, the door! Where you from anyhow, Alaska?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Wisconsin.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Same general idea.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: So long, Ho-Jon.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: You make a mean martini, kid.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Us. Lead us not into...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: ...No cases over the age of temptation but deliver us eight. from evil. For Thine is the kingdom, the power and...

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SPEARCHUCKER
turns.text: When he sees a little running room, he likes to make a show... you know, stutter steps and cross-overs and all that jazz. Also he never learned to button up when he gets hit, so if you two can get a good shot at him once, you can hurt him.

turns.speaker: SPEARCHUCKER
turns.text: We got to stop them right here.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: And get ourselves another touchdown to win.  I wish to hell we knew what they were plotting.

turns.speaker: SPEARCHUCKER
turns.text: You mind if we get out of this guy's brain first?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What's there to do? You found the sliver.

turns.speaker: SPEARCHUCKER
turns.text: There might be another tiny piece we missed. I want to look around before we close up.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Perfectionist.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: My name's Hawkeye Pierce.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Duke Forrest.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: You got directions?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Ayuh, only it's early, I need a drink to wake me up.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: I got some.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Make it yourself, or is it real?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Georgia, where I come from, it's real if you make it yourself. But I been buying from the Yankee Government since they put me in this soldier suit and give me a rate.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Tax-free booze. It's about all you can say for army life.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Where you from with that crazy way of talking?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Crabapple Cove. Maine.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Damn! That must be about as far north as you can get.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Pretty near. What do you know about the outfit we're going to?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: C.O. is Colonel Blake. Lieutenant Colonel Henry Braymore Blake. One of them regular army clowns. Push you around so it's hard to get any decent work done.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: We got to head them off, right at the start. Push them around first.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What's the initials 'MP' stand for, Hawkeye?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Shore Patrol, Duke. Let's go!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Must be the Famous Curb Service Whore   House. You in the market Duke?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: I done my shopping in Seoul last night.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Well, there it is. Jesus!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: The spot we picked to spend the winter. Maybe we ought to look a little harder.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What do you think of that piece of scenery, Yankee boy?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Finest kind. We'll sit where we can get the best view.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Colonel Blake, have no fear. Hawkeye and Duke are here.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: That's right, pal. You just sit up front and sign the mail, and leave the cutting to us.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Little light reading matter. Just right for his age.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Well, southern boy, I suppose you want the sack that's convenient to the door.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: And gets the wind every time it opens. No, thanks. I'll take that one.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: This kid's ready but we won't know all the damage till we get in and see what's happened. What have you got?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Nothing can't wait. Shall we check it out with the Major?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Now that's what I call real pretty. We can close up here and go into his belly.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: He can't take much more time on the table.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: So we got to cut him fast. I figure from the X-ray it ain't just the spleen. We also got to snatch his right kidney.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Christ Almighty, I think he means it!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: We been had.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: We've stuck it out for a whole week now... Pretty girl.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: We sure don't aim to cause any trouble... Yeah, she seems to grow on you.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: No, Hawkeye just said it all.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Except we forgot one other small thing.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: The chest-cutter.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Yeah, that's right.  You better get us a chest-cutter before there's trouble.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: This outfit needs somebody who can find his way around the pulmonary anatomy when the bases are loaded.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: And it's the ninth inning.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Jesus to Jesus and eight hands around! Duke, did I ever tell you how I beat Dartmouth by intercepting a pass?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Sixteen times.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: We didn't have a chance, little Androscoggin College against the Big Green, but there was this blizzard and we held then nothing nothing till the last twenty seconds. Then this great passer of theirs let one go, snow and all...

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Must be Painlees Pole Day in the Shower Tent.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: You met him. Walt Waldowski, the Dental Officer.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Nice guy, for an enamel surgeon.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Best equipped dentist in the whole goddam Army. Care to have a look, a man with your background?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Way we hear it, the Pride is supposed to have run up the highest lifetime batting average ever recorded in Wayne County.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: This kid looks like a loser. Maybe we better get the bead-jiggler to put in a fix.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Call Dago Red.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: And you've had a natural four times in a row in a crap game. Right? Does that mean...?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Not without lots of praying and kissing the dice.  It's a different ritual but it works the same.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What do you think, Trapper?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Y'all just act natural.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Get out the scotch, Ho-Jon.  Don't mention the sex thing unless he brings it up.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: That there Frank Burns is a menace. Whenever a patient croaks on him it's either God's will or somebody else's fault.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: This time he did it to a kid who's simple enough to believe him. Why don't you dump the mother, Henry? He creates more work than he gets done.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Hail to the chief! We-all got a responsibility, men. He's crowned like a king ought to be, but he can't just walk to the Mess Hall by himself. He has to be carried by native bearers.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Good thinking, Duke. How about it, Ho-Jon? Can you round up a few of the boys?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Never mind. Forget it.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: A native is someone who is born in a particular place.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: When will he be able to write?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: What's he got to write, for God's sake?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: An application to Androscoggin College.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I guess that's why you go for Hot Lips Houlihan.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: You know damn well I nearly puke when I look at her. I don't even think she's a real blonde.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: How can you say a thing like that about an officer in the United States Army?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: I not only say it, I'll back it up twenty buck's worth.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: You got yourself a bet, Georgia boy.  You're a witness.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Where the hell we going to get us a football team?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: All three of us played for our schools. And there are at least four other guys...

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Never heard of him.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Sure you have, only as 'Spearchucker' Jones.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: The nigra boy with the Philadelphia Eagles?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: How come nobody knows about him? And you do?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I worked with Spearchucker my first month over here, at the 72nd Evac in Taegu. Most of the colored guys know who he is but they're not talking because he asked them not to.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Now wait a minute, Hawkeye. I come a long way, learning to put up with a couple of crazy Yankees, but...

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Don't tell me about your problems, boy. Explain them to Ho-Jon.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Look at the size of those two beasts.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I don't think I could hurt one of them with a sledgehammer.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Don't try to get it far down. Kick it up high so we can get there and surround that son-ofa-bitch.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Yeah, if I can.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Me, too. Y'all just seen me play my last game.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Same here. You can retire my number.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Henry's got our orders! We're going home!

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Any time. Whenever we want.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Be right with you.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: There's no transportation anyway this time of night.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: We could steal one of the choppers.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I looked. Suspicious bastards got them all locked up.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: I thought we were heading for trouble putting on all these trinkets.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: We got to start rehabilitating, Duke, if we want to be halfway human by the time we get back to our wives.

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: But no short-arm inspection. I'm with you there.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Screw it. We been earning our keep as respectable knife artists. Why should we do work any pill-rolling punk could handle?

turns.speaker: DUKE
turns.text: Hell, man, that don't matter. We're loaded. We were big wheels in the black market in Seoul.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Plus running the opium concession for the whole Eighth Army.
